source.title: Montane Alternative Silvicultural Systems (MASS) – harvesting productivity and cost comparisons
source.site: Interior cedar-hemlock zone near Adams Lake, BC; 1995–1996 MASS experiment with replicated clearcut, patch cut, green-tree retention, and shelterwood treatments.
source.notes: Falling done manually; forwarding done with excavator-based 'serpentine' patterns plus tracked skidder cleanup.

forwarding.notes: Excavator 1 worked between corridors; tracked skidder forwarded along shot corridors to roadside.

treatments.notes: Highest retention; extra corridor cleanup and tracked skidder relay increased cost ~61% over clearcut forwarding.

forwarding.notes: Serpentine forwarding with excavators; tracked skidder assisted where logs were misaligned.

treatments.notes: Leave-tree clumps forced shorter passes (23 m average) and higher grapple/position time.

forwarding.notes: Serpentine pattern allowed 27 m pass spacing; tracked skidder only used for training clean-up.

treatments.notes: Shorter forwarding distances but more complex layout kept total cost ~10% above clearcut baseline.

forwarding.notes: Excavators forwarded directly to roadside decks laid out for super-snorkel loading.

treatments.notes: Acts as the baseline for MASS comparisons; highest productivity due to unrestricted serpentine forwarding.
